boardgame.name: Franchise Hockey Manager 6
boardgame.description: Franchise Hockey Manager returns for the 2019-20 season with plenty of additions to the deepest, most authentic hockey strategy gaming experience you can find. Choose one of 32 leagues around the globe and select a team to guide to glory, including a chance at the ultimate prize, the Stanley Cup®.

boardgame.name: The Precursors (Fan Expansion for Magic: The Gathering)
boardgame.description:
Magic: The Gathering - The Precursors is a cooperative board game and card variant of the classic, competitive card game that has players work together in an epic campaign that can span several gaming sessions. It utilizes a slightly altered Commander (EDH) format of MTG.

Similar to Dungeons & Dragons, a Dungeon Master — or a Game Master (GM), in this case — guides up to four other players on a series of six quests, each of which takes about two to three hours to complete.

The players start in one of the zones. If it’s the Red zone, they’ll be facing a Red or Multicoloured commander; the Blue zone, they’ll be facing a Blue or Multicoloured commander; etc. Each quest features a new enemy deck, so no two quests are ever the same.

The GM is given certain card and life advantages over the Precursor heroes, and it is the goal of the Precursors to defeat the GM while working together. Also of note is that the game allows the GM to also play as one of the heroes if they’re up to it. This means that the game supports up to five players.

The game is quite affordable as it allows cards from every single MTG set. The players make their decks with whatever cards they want to use, a single commander (Legendary Creature) overseeing the army of cards.

The board game consists of five different phases, two of which are almost identical to traditional duels. The game’s pretty simple to learn for veteran Magic players, and not much more difficult than the card game itself for new Magic players.

NOTE: This game is unofficial, of course.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Frontier Explorer (Issue 29 - Summer 2020)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Welcome to issue 29 of the Frontier Explorer. We kick off the issue with a new ship by a new author, Shawn Starky, detailing a small hull size 4 freighter. We are also introducing a new series, “An Alternate Frontier,” by another new author, Richard “GreyMyst” Farris. The first article, Electrochemical Slugthrowers, looks basic projectile weap-ons and provides a variety of new models. Future articles will look at other weapons and develop his version of an alternate Frontier.

We again have two more installments of the “Things that go Boom!” series, which should wrap up with a final article next issue. This time we’re looking at dropped ordinance – bombs.

We round out the issue with our usual comics, another article from Jurak Hangna, a look at the Battle of Zebulon, a book review, and a new bit of equipment from the Minzi Marketplace.

The full article list is:

Pah’Thas – Hull Size 4 Freighter
Things that go Boom 7 – Looking at Dropped Weapons
Knight Hawk Scenarios: Battle of Zebulon
Percival's Legacy!
Titian Rising: 2299
In the Minzii Marketplace: Inertia Umbrella
Electrochemical Slugthrowers – Sluggers
Book Review: Ultimate RPG Character Backstory Guide
Things that go Boom 8 – More Bombs, Targeting, and Aerial Drop Systems
boardgame.rpgissuearticle: Book Review: The Ultimate RPG Character Backstory Guide
In the Minzii Marketplace: Inertia Umbrella
Things That Go Boom Part 7 Looking at Dropped Weapons
Things That Go Boom Part 8: More Bombs, Targeting, and Aerial Drop Systems

boardgame.name: Those Dark Places
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Space is a hell of a thing but you need to be sure that this is what you want. Like, what you really want. The idea of space exploration to further the frontiers of mankind is noble, but let's not kid ourselves – it’s really all about furthering the profit margins. There’s money to be made and out there is the place to make it, but you hear all kinds of stories… equipment malfunctions, strange discoveries, crewmembers going insane... You'll be out there in the reaches, alone, for months or years, breathing recycled air and drinking recycled water, with nothing but a few feet of metal and shielding between you and certain death.

Are you sure this is what you want?
– Crew Orientation Briefing

Those Dark Places is a rules-light, story-focused roleplaying game about the darker side of space exploration and the people who travel the stars in claustrophobic, dangerous conditions. Starships, stations, and outposts aren't havens of safety with clean, brightly lit corridors – they're potential deathtraps, funded by budget-conscious corporate interests and running on stale, recycled air and water. The stars may be the future of humanity, but they are also home to horrors and terror the human mind cannot comprehend.

boardgame.name: Darringmoor: City of Shadows
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"Strange, keenings seem to be much more frequent here and last far longer than in any other place I have visited. There is much to learn from this city.”-
A quote from the Famous Ormocean Cleric Rallid.

Darringmoor: City of Shadows is a setting for a fantasy role playing game and details a medieval port of strategic importantance which lies on the border of three countries – Sard, Llan and Elkia. Darringmoor is located within Sirrith’s Veil, a region where the fabric of existence between the world of Enshar and the Undead realm of Shadowland has been weakened, resulting in a long history of incursions by Undead creatures. This source material comes complete with the background history of the Darringmoor, its traditions, politics, and religious institutions. It also provides a GM with a wealth of information concerning major NPCs, events, and plots for the GM to get their players involved with.

While this book is written as a supplement for a GM who is running a campaign based in Eldoria, there is nothing stopping you from transplanting any of the ideas contained in this book to your own alternate setting.

boardgame.name: The Helm of Radiance (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Discover the mystery of the Helm of Radiance!

The Helm of Radiance is a 6 page drop-in adventure for Fifth Edition that can be used in most fantasy settings for 1st or 2nd level characters. The Helm of Radiance can be used in your campaigns, or as a 1-3 hour one-shot adventure.

The Helm of Radiance includes:

Explore the Cave of Whispers, a reportedly haunted locale.


Solve a riddle of incredible danger.

Solve the mystery of The Helm of Radiance with several possible player determined outcomes!

boardgame.name: Courting Death
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

5th Edition Mini-Dungeon for four characters of level 8

Victory and tragedy have befallen the Duchy of Pequniel. The foul necromancer Lodira has been defeated, her undead armies driven from the field. Yet the price was high. The old duke is dead, fallen in battle against the loathsome horde.

It has been a fortnight and the duke’s heir has since laid his father to rest in the family vault. Now the time of mourning is nearly done. The new Duke Pequniel prepares for his elevation ceremony. Rich trappings and eager young noblewomen are scheduled to arrive; all the duchy’s wagging tongues wonder whether their young lord-to-be will find a duchess. Unfortunately, the new duke isn’t the only one with suitors. For the necromancer Lodira is something of a social climber, and death is no barrier for a determined gold digger.

Once a romantic rival of the late Duchess Pequniel, Lodira turned to dark magic when the old duke chose another. She has since made it her business to plague the duchy with undead monsters. Having survived her recent defeat, Lodira now plans to turn it to her advantage. Her latest batch of minions have waylaid the caravans carrying banquet supplies, dragging them to the dead duke’s tomb. As the adventure begins, Lodira is studying furiously to learn the art of resurrection, and plans to charm the duke and win his hand once he returns to the lands of the living.

boardgame.name: Horrific Curses (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Curses of Doom!

Horrific Curses will bring your 5E characters to their knees begging for mercy from this collection of curses! This book brings you brand new accursed character options, including the accursed witch warlock, the hex hunter ranger, and the jinxed sorcerer. It also introduces a new category of magic, the dying spell, with 10 new spells like call the avenger and funeral pyre to allow heroes and villains alike to cast their spite upon their foes with their dying breath. Add to this nearly 20 brand-new curses from famine's feast and labile lunacy to kinslayer and hatemonger's halo, with each one as detailed as it is diabolical to create memorable curse effects that are vividly virulent. If you've ever wanted your curses to be more than just a simple spell, something to inspire delightful terror in your players, bring home the horror that only curses can deliver!

boardgame.name: Floors & Trapdoors (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of great features and details to add to the floors and trapdoors in your dungeon. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Floors and Trapdoors is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Floors & Trapdoors (OSR)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of great features and details to add to the floors and trapdoors in your dungeon. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Floors and Trapdoors is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Floors & Trapdoors (PF1)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of great features and details to add to the floors and trapdoors in your dungeon. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Floors and Trapdoors is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Floors & Trapdoors (PF2)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of great features and details to add to the floors and trapdoors in your dungeon. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Floors and Trapdoors is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Laurels and Lilies
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Ascendency is a major sporting event in the Casabelle calendar. Each year, massive crowds gather to watch darning drivers tackle a gruelling high-speed course in their powerful flyers. The race takes place in the city hinterlands with a course so dangerous that only the bravest participate. Death is not uncommon during this event, but the prize money and the glory ensure a host of willing drivers. The event is the keystone of the local government’s plan to maintain morale in the city and cancelling it would be disastrous for the economy. Unfortunately, this is exactly what one person wants to happen.

A quick and easy jumpstart adventure for the MYTHIC D6 Terra Oblivion game world.

Included:

A 5-page adventure
Adversary Write-Ups
Pre-generated player heroes

boardgame.name: Denizens of Filth
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The cities and towns of Rûl are islands of civilization that provide a refuge from the horrors in the uninhabited parts of the land. Behind their walls and barred gates, citizens feel safe from what lurks outside. Content in their homes, few of them realize that the tunnels and sewers under their feet teem with sinister creatures and foul abominations that wallow in the filth, looking for the right moment to snatch a fresh meal.

One such terror is the creature that most people call the filth goblin. This offshoot of the goblin race thrives and multiplies in the fetid sewers, privies, and waterways that flow beneath the largest towns and cities. Their primary form of sustenance is humanoid waste—the warmer and fresher the better. Few citizens sitting down to do their bodily business realize that something sinister might lurk mere feet or inches away.

boardgame.name: Near Space
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

While the world circa 350 years from now seems Utopian, that actually is not the case. People are still self-serving and often work against one another. Privilege and opportunity are meted out by location and family more often than by need or merit. Incorporated interests still strive to exploit the resources available to them and then deprive those not part of their franchise. But things are still a whole lot better for all the human population than ever before. Speaking of population, that population is bigger than ever and only getting bigger. This could explain why space exploration and colonization is bigger than military arms – overcrowding without starvation just gets people adventurous.

Space is the place.

boardgame.name: Wanted in the Wastes (SF)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Wastes Await!

Journey across the parched wastes of Akasaat beyond the shores of the Bleaching Sea in search of a fugitive spellcaster hunted by the agents of the tireless Vanguard Order! Discover the secrets of the forbidden spaces in the desert's heart, through scouring storms, bone-eating raiders, and a lost city that was long a haven but might become a deathtrap. Choose a side between the militant Hierarchy and the liberty-seeking Riders and make your mark on the incredible worlds of the Aethera system!

Wanted in the Wastes is a Starfinder Roleplaying Game adventure for 1st-level characters set in the best-selling Aethera Campaign Setting and introduces your players to the wonders of this incredibly detailed universe of sci-fi fantasy adventure with touches of cosmic horror and steampunk noir!

boardgame.name: Death in the Dark
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In these collection of two adventures for Gods and Masters, travel outside the walls of Dokaro, to solve two important mysteries.

In Flames in the Footlands, imperial and shadow warrior PCs must investigate the cause of several fire that have been raging across all the rural settlements of Dorva.

In Pathway of the Gods, heroes from any faction stumble upon the clues that lead them into a Celestial ruin, where wonders and dangers beyond understanding can be found in every musty corner, and the answers to centuries-old questions await discovery.

Players can use character of their own making, or use the ones in the free JumpStart, available here. These difficult missions are recommended for heroes of Seasoned rank or higher.

boardgame.name: Vem sa så?
boardgame.description: I Vem sa så? (Who said so?) you should tell who said the memorable quotes. You can compete yourself, challenge an opponent or everyone responds at the same time.

boardgame.name: More Demons
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Introduce some true evil to your Savage Worlds game by including Monster Brief: More Demons. In this product you will find:

The Ala, a shape changing monster who seeks to connect mortals but whose temperament can become stormy and deadly with rejection.
The Lilin are masters of arcane magic -- it literally flows through their veins -- and so they are forever seeking mystic power.
The Shuck, or "black dog," is a demonic harbinger of plague and ill-fortune.
The Soul Trader, also known as "Hell's genies," seek out mortals to impart their demonic pact gifts to in exchange for their mortal souls, one piece at a time.

boardgame.name: United States v. Aaron Burr
boardgame.description:
Many events in American history have been labeled "trials of the century", but for a young nation, it would have been impossible to top United States v. Aaron Burr. Unlike Washington, Jefferson, Madison or Hamilton, Aaron Burr came from American royalty — a founding father descended from the original puritanical stock that arrived in Plymouth. His father was the second president of Princeton. His grandfather was Jonathan Edwards, the philosopher-theologian who wrote "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God," perhaps the most important American literary work of its time.

So in 1776, if you were going to identify any of the Founders who would later stand trial for treason to his country, Aaron Burr would be the least likely — yet Burr's journey as an enormous talent born under a dark star is now well known. Less well understood is that when he shot Alexander Hamilton in the early morning hours of July 11, 1804, it would set in motion a chain of events much more bizarre than anything depicted on Broadway.

Aaron Burr never stood trial for killing Alexander Hamilton in a duel. His trial was for treason, three years later, at the insistence of the Thomas Jefferson, the man Burr had narrowly lost to in the contested election of 1800. An embittered and politically ruined Burr seemed to have developed a scheme to separate the new Louisiana Purchase territories from the United States and declare himself king over the new entity. When Jefferson learned of the plot, he ordered Burr's arrest and publicly declared him guilty of treason.

United States v. Aaron Burr: The Treason Trial of America's Third Vice President, a card-driven game for two players, recreates the treason trial of Aaron Burr in Richmond in 1807. But by accident of recent judicial reforms, Thomas Jefferson's detested cousin, Chief Justice John Marshall, would be riding circuit and would preside over the case. The resulting legal contest would read like a list of who's who of America's Founding Fathers.

United States vs. Aaron Burr is a fast-playing card-driven game in which players seek to use events, evidence, and witnesses of Burr's activities to convince a jury to return a guilty verdict — or if playing for the defense, persuade at least one juror to find Aaron Burr not guilty. Each round, players have the opportunity to question witnesses, persuade jurors, and make points of law to the Chief Justice which will aid them in their cause. The game highlights all the events and participants surrounding one of the most important trials in American Constitutional Law — setting the precedent that the President of the United States is NOT immune from legal court orders, a precedent very much cited by the Supreme Court today.

So try your hand as a great litigator in a great trial. Perhaps you will even find yourself smiling more and talking less!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

boardgame.name: In the Pass
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for three to six Gilory Road Roleplay player-characters. It can follow the adventure "At the High Point Inn," (AtHPI) but new characters can be added or an entirely new party might be introduced.

This is a much more linear adventure than AtHPI, with the goal of getting from point A to point B as safely as possible. However, there are decisions to be made that can change things. This adventure may end at Iron Town in The Black Mountain District (on our website) and can be rounded out with some events and encounters there.

boardgame.name: OSR In the Pass
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for three to six OSR/D20 player-characters. It can follow the adventure "At the High Point Inn," (AtHPI) but new characters can be added or an entirely new party might be introduced.

This is a much more linear adventure than AtHPI, with the goal of getting from point A to point B as safely as possible. However, there are decisions to be made that can change things. This adventure may end at Iron Town in The Black Mountain District (on our website) and can be rounded out with some events and encounters there.

boardgame.name: NOVA: Race from the Sun
boardgame.description:
Centuries into the future, scientists experimenting with fusion technology have triggered the Sun to go Super Nova! To escape the expanding corona, players must mine resources, manage their crew population and research sufficient technology to traverse actual locations in our Solar System and escape into the greater Milky Way Galaxy.

On a turn, players have a variable number of actions to perform based on their Crew size. Actions include Mining (taking a resource die from their current planet or moon), Researching (gaining a technology card for new abilities), and Traveling (attempting a roll with resource dice to get to the next orbital location away from the sun). There are also interactive actions between players including Hacking (stealing a technology card), Spying (using another player's tech), and Attacking to steal a resource.

The ultimate goal is to escape the Sun's corona beyond Pluto and into the greater Milky Way with the highest number of crew.

The base game contains a Solar System board, 10 transparent corona covers, and over 75 dice in 8 different colors, 49 technology cards and 4 spaceship player markers.

NOVA: Race from the Sun also features a distinct Solo Mode with 864 possible combinations of technology and a unique scoring system for high replayability.

Write your chapter in humanity's Solar saga!

-description from designer
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: NOVA: Race from the Sun 5th Player Expansion

boardgame.name: OSR Into the Westwood
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an OSR/D20 adventure for low-level characters. Characters who have been through [ “OSR At the High Point Inn”] and [ “OSR In the Pass”] could be used or new characters could be introduced. Combining some of the experienced characters with some new characters would be fine.

The basic adventure, going from the Barony to the Isolated Hills, should take two or three sessions but there are several available side trips that could tempt the characters into adventures lasting much longer. A GM who wished to could have travelers using this adventure, adjusting for what has gone before, several times.

boardgame.name: Into the Westwood
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is a Glory Road Roleplay adventure for low-level characters. Characters who have been through "At the High Point Inn" and [ “In the Pass”] could be used or new characters could be introduced. Combining some of the experienced characters with some new characters would be fine.

The basic adventure, going from the Barony to the Isolated Hills, should take two or three sessions but there are several available side trips that could tempt the characters into adventures lasting much longer. A GM who wished to could have travelers using this adventure, adjusting for what has gone before, several times.

boardgame.name: 十六夜小町 (Izayoi)
boardgame.description:
Izayoi (十六夜小町) is a board game where players race to collect 16 types of wakomono and compete for points. The game is for 3 to 5 people and it can be played in 15 minutes.

One player places a recommendation card on the field. Depending on the number of votes one of the players will earn the wakomono. There are also some unique rules, and it also requires strict hand management. Players aim for the highest score, but they should not exceed their master's score. Eventually, if a player's score exceeds his/her master's, the player will be dropped from the game. This mirrors Japanese culture in which one should be “polite” and not make the master lose face.

boardgame.name: Mondragon Keep
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for five or six Glory Road player-characters who have reached fifth through seventh level. Characters who have gone through the [ “Under the Abandoned Monastery”] adventure and one or more of the adventures that precede it would be suitable. It is also possible to create characters at a suitable level.

Mondragon has generally been pronounced MONdruhgone, the first and last syllables nearly rhyme.

boardgame.name: OSR Mondragon Keep
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for five or six OSR/D20 player-characters who have reached fifth through seventh level. Characters who have gone through the [ “OSRUnder the Abandoned Monastery”] adventure and one or more of the adventures that precede it would be suitable. It is also possible to create characters at a suitable level.

Mondragon has generally been pronounced MONdruhgone, the first and last syllables nearly rhyme.

boardgame.name: Grimasjakten
boardgame.description: A player takes a card and tries to copy the grimace shown on the card. The other players should now try to see which grimace it is and as soon as possible mark the correct picture on the game board.

boardgame.name: OSR Under the Abandoned Monastery
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for four to six OSR/D20 player- characters with some experience. A group that has experienced the module [ “OSR Into the Westwood”] or the twin introductory modules [ “OSR At the High Point Inn”] and [ “OSR In the Pass”] or both would be suitable. If they have some replacements or additions, even if those are only first level, that is perfectly fine. All values for treasure are given in the Silver Penny $ of Glon.’ In this adventure, we see again the factional conflict that complicates life in The Black Mountain District as we saw in the adventures “OSR At the High Point Inn” and “OSR In the Pass.”

The adventure is challenging and the players should not feel that they have to get all the way through without a return to civilization for resupply and reinforcement. Time to play the adventure has varied from three to six sessions.

boardgame.name: Under the Abandoned Monastery
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for four to six Glory Road Roleplay characters with some experience. A group that has experienced the module [ “Into the Westwood”] or the twin introductory modules "At the High Point Inn" and [ “In the Pass”] or both would be suitable. If they have some replacements or additions, even if those are only first level, that is perfectly fine. All values for treasure are given in the Silver Penny $ of Glon.’ In this adventure, we see again the factional conflict that complicates life in The Black Mountain District as we saw in the adventures “At the High Point Inn” and “In the Pass.”

The adventure is challenging and the players should not feel that they have to get all the way through without a return to civilization for resupply and reinforcement. Time to play the adventure has varied from three to six sessions.

boardgame.name: OSR At the High Point Inn
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an OSR/D20 version of At the High Point Inn, an adventure for three to six beginning Player-characters. The way the adventure goes will depend on decisions by the characters and the GM. When it is completed and the group likes it, the next adventure, [ "In the Pass,"] follows naturally.

This inn and the staff can be used for further adventures, with new guests, PCs and NPCs, or as a stopping place between adventures.

boardgame.name: Aventuras de 1 Página: A Invasão Ninja
The Ninja Invasion
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

1Page Adventures is a serie of adventures to you adapt to any RPG system. A perfect plot to start a new campaing or to put in between of your adventures in the most different worlds!


Aventuras de 1 Página é uma séria para adaptar para em qualquer sistema. Um plot perfeito para começar a jogar ou colocar entre suas aventuras, nos mais diversos cenários e ambientações!

Kill or Die in Westport

From publisher blurb:

boardgame.name: Sakura Extra Box
boardgame.description:
Every spring, the cherry trees blossom all over Japan. The Japanese celebrate this occasion, as according to their traditions the goddess of Fuji mountain, Konohana Sakuya Hima, revives the fallen flowers at this time. The cherry flower is a symbol of vitality called "sakura".

The players in Sakura aim to play cards without taking any hands. They have to play two cards each time, one on each side of the Jin-Jang card following the rules, which by default require higher number on the Jin side and lower on the Jang side in the same color. (Alternatively, a player can place the same number in any color.) Also, the players are aided in their success by several characters, who require payment (money). The game ends when everyone has only two cards left in their hand. The player who earns the fewest points wins the favor of the goddess and glory will be theirs until next spring.


This edition contains previous Kickstarter extras (not exclusive).

boardgame.name: Brått i Valleby
boardgame.description:
The game is based on the popular Swedish children's books about LasseMajas detektivbyrå (LasseMaja's detective agency) by Martin Widmark & Helena Willis. The books are about two children, Lasse and Maja, who solve mysteries and crimes in the fictional town of Valleby.

In the game, each participant gets one of the known mysteries from the books and must then as fast as possible bring the four suspects and one of the detectives to the crime scene. Whoever succeeds in it first wins.

On each mystery card, four suspects are listed. The suspects on all mystery cards as well as the two detectives Lasse and Maja and also the police chief (who is also one of the detectives) are placed around the playing field with the help of a dice. In turn, you roll the dice and either move one of your suspects or one of the detectives (who are all used by all the players) towards the building that their mystery card has listed.

In addition to this, each player has cards on hand that can either help one to move their suspects faster towards the right building or move the opponents' suspects further away from their building. Among the cards, there are also cards that give you the opportunity to take cards from an opponent, roll one more time with the dice, get the opportunity to use the cable car, etc. Every time you move one of the game characters into a building marked with an arrow, you have to draw new cards to your hand.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Who in the Room?
boardgame.description:
Who in the room would surivive the least amount of time on a desert island? Who in the room pees in the shower? Who in the room has the best voice for radio? And who in the room would have the most trouble assembling a bookcase from IKEA?

Who in the room…? is an addictively entertaining party game that reveals what you and your friends really think about each other. The game has more than 300 laugh-out-loud, unexpected, and personal questions that all start with the phrase Who in the room…?

Draw a card, read the question out loud, and give everyone a few seconds to think. At the count of three, everyone points to who they think best fits the question's description.

Be prepared for dropped jaws and hilarious discussions to follow!

Who in the room…? is the perfect game for your next party, dinner, or get-together!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Age of Fantasy: Regiments
boardgame.description:
Age of Fantasy: Regiments is a miniature wargame set in a dark magical world, which is played using 28mm miniatures.
The game mechanics are designed to be easy to learn but hard to master, bringing engaging regimental fantasy battles for new and experienced players alike.

This rulebook adds lots of extra content to the core rules, providing you with countless hours of epic regimental battles that you can customize however you like.
The rules are written to be concise and to the point, and come with beautiful illustrations as well as helpful example diagrams.

Here's everything that's included in this rulebook:

Core Rules
Advanced Rules
Terrain Placement
Deployment Styles
Extra Missions
Side-Missions
Extra Actions
Solid Buildings
Random Events
Battlefield Conditions
Terrain & Objective Effects

Total Conversions
Fog of War
Brutal Damage
Command Points
Fatigue
Phased Battles
Multiplayer Games
Small-Scales & Multi-Basing



Note that all of the army books are available for free on the publisher website, and are not part of this rulebook.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: PUSSY 3

User Summary

boardgame.name: Rrypo: Get A Head
ЯR¥P⊙: GetꞏAꞏHead
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Get A Head is rules-loose science fantasy rpg module inspired by the fantastically ridiculous Boorman movie Zardoz. A trail of destruction and devastation leads to a head-shaped flying fortress protected by gun-wielding savages. Will they manage to capture it?

compatible with the Ultraviolet Grasslands and Seacat
moral conundrums and vicious raiders
different approaches to getting inside the head
illustrated split-level map of the head
five strange NPCs
15-room breakdown of the head
guidelines for heroes operating the head
game changes and new goals if they take over the head
30 possible challenges encountered while flying the malfunctioning giant head

boardgame.name: アマビエレース (AMABIE RACING)
boardgame.description:
アマビエレース ～オレが、わたしが、アマビエだ～ (Amabie resu - orega, watashiga, Amabie da -) (AMABIE RACING - The true Amabie is me -) is a game from Japan.

In Japan, there is a long history of folklore creatures known as Yokai, various weird monsters, spirits and demons, some malign, some benign. Amabie is onesuch benign creature that appeared in 1846, with a promise to dispel a pandemic. Long forgotten, with the arrival of COVID-19 in Japan, the image of Amabie has been revived widely. In this game players try to race to be the creature rising from the waters and claim to be the real Amabie.
user summary

Faster than other players, jump out from the sea water and claim "I am Amabie."
Use items wisely and take advance of the race.
The keys of the game are 'prophet', 'items', and 'fortune'.

・一番に海から飛び出し「わたしがアマビエだ」と言い張ろう
・アイテムを使いこなしてレースを有利に進めよう
・勝負の決め手は「予言」「アイテム」「時の運」
publisher's summary

boardgame.name: Clownspel
boardgame.description:
The game board is divided into four circles, one for each color. In the circles there are fields in different colors that each player must walk along until they reach the last field which is the only gray field. The players move by rolling a color dice, i.e. you move to the nearest field with that color. To win, you must first have rolled black on the dice so that you get the black hat and then roll gray to reach the last field. If you roll gray before you have the black hat, you will instead have to stand over a roll.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Reign
Reign: The Final Battle Royal
boardgame.description:
Four factions of warriors battle to survive on a doomed land that will be destroyed piece by piece, taking its occupants with it. You must strategize to survive—by fleeing, fighting or sacrificing your weakest members—whatever you must do to be the last one left standing when the land around you has been annihilated.

Be the last one standing in a strategic fight to survive The Final Battle Royale!

•On each turn, you can move three spaces and/or battle an opponent.
•Watch as the Event Tracker counts down to the removal of one of the game board zones—get out before you lose members of your faction or choose to sacrifice those pieces.
•When a zone is removed, a new Card is turned over to indicate the next zone to be removed.
•Use Power Stones to make more moves or help win battles.
•When you land in a space on the Game Board next to another player’s faction member, you can choose to battle.
•To battle, each player involved rolls their Battle Die. The value they rolled, plus the value of their faction member, is their battle power. The player with the highest battle power wins the battle. The losing piece is removed from the Game Board.

The last player with a faction member(s) left on the Game Board is the winner of The Final Battle Royale!

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: TAISAKU BUILDING 感染症対策ソロデッキ構築型ゲーム (TAISAKU BUILDING Kansenshotaisaku soro dekkikouchikugata gemu)
boardgame.description:
TAISAKU BUILDING 感染症対策ソロデッキ構築型ゲーム (TAISAKU BUILDING kansenshotaisaku soro dekkikouchikugata gemu) (TAISAKU BUILDING Anti-Infectious Disease Solo Deck Construction Game) is a solitaire deck-building game from Japan. Uisng two decks mixed, it can be played by two players alternating turns.

The game has a series of monsters that attack the player with various infectious diseases. The player must use appropriate medical counter-measure cards to fend off and defeat the enemies. If they can stop all five of the enemies, they win. If they run out of hit points, they lose.

The game allows the player to alter the difficulty level of the game in preparation. The game warns the reader to not take it as proper medical advice.
user summary

- A solo deck construction game.
- Setback the viruses with proper prophylaxes and countermeasures.
- The difficulty can be adjusted as you like! Can you clear the highest difficulty!?

・１人でできるデッキ構築型ゲーム
・ウイルスを対策で打ち倒せ！
・難易度調整可能！ 最高難易度をクリアできるか！？
publisher's summary

boardgame.name: Lachen, Lachen
Lachen, Lachen, Lachen
Skratt, Skratt, Skratt
boardgame.description:
Lachen, Lachen, Lachen is a party game, there are question cards and answer cards, both stacks are shuffled, the top question card is read aloud and then the top answer card is read, the fun lies in the comic of the combinations.

If the cards have the same color, they are put out of play, but if they have different colors, they are placed in a pile in front of the person who answered the question. The game continues until someone gets rid of all the cards.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Happy Mothers Slay: Motherhood on the Hunt
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Inside, you'll find:

A celebration of motherhood in #iHunt. Both hunter mommies and monster mommies.
A guide to what life is like on the hunt with a kid.
Tools for bringing a child into the stories responsibly.
New monsters!

boardgame.name: The Anarchist's Meal Kit Delivery Service: The Hunt During Civil Unrest
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Anarchist's Meal Kit Delivery Service is the seventh in a series of "Zine Supplements" for #iHunt: The RPG. Or as we'd like to call them, "Zupplements."

The Anarchist's Meal Kit Delivery Service is a series of pieces on how the hunt works in times of civil unrest. It's a thing on everyone's mind right now, but instead of trying to bring a specific event into the #iHunt world, it acknowledges that civil unrest and mass movements are part of our day-to-day life right now, and addresses how that affects the monster hunting world. #iHunt is a game about 2020. Welcome to 2020.

Mutual Aid. This is about life during mass upheaval, but on the hunt. It’s got a few rules hacks reflecting the unique circumstances of mass movement. Also my talking about the time I got tear gassed.
Rebel Radio. It’s full of ideas for hunts taking place during times of upheaval.
Attack and Dethrone God. This is about the hunt itself on the streets. How you can fight in crowded spaces, and use crowds to your advantage.
Protests Work. It’s a little essay talking about how you can let mass movements influence the world of your game and manage that with realistic expectations.
Side By Side With A Friend. It’s two monsters that will work with hunters. One’s a witch who is glad to work in the background of a hunt. The other’s a werewolf who will get the fuck up and fight alongside the right cause.
Call to Action. It’s a list of causes you can get involved with right now, just to get your brain pumping or whatever. Also, from a game perspective, looking into how some of these groups organize can help make your stories feel more authentic.

boardgame.name: Fun in the Sun: Hunting on the Beach
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Fun in the Sun is the eighth in a series of "Zine Supplements" for #iHunt: The RPG. Or as we'd like to call them, "Zupplements."

We're all drained from all this pandemic nonsense, and we WANT TO GET OUT INTO THE SUN. So, we did a zine all about hunting monsters on the California beaches.
This includes:

Slaywatch! A guide to hunting on the beach, a new Fate action called Force Movement, and some ideas about how stuff works in the water. Fun!
Monsters of the Deep. A guide to some oceanic monsters, including merfolk, krakens, drowned sailors, and all sorts of other fun shit. Oh! Also weresharks.
Shadow Over Hypatia. A fully fleshed adventure kit, ready for your beach adventure time fun.

boardgame.name: A Spring Court Quest
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Duet Adventure for PCs of levels 3-5
Travel to the enchanting forests and colorful fields of the Fae Brightlands...
...and join a search for the mystical miniature fae unicorn—a pseudocorn!

An intrepid showman, Gavin Desantis, approaches the party with a request that he’s willing to make well worth their while—for 3000gp, would they be willing to do him the small favor of traveling to the Fae Brightlands?

Gavin specializes in exotic animals and their acquisition for display in his menagerie. He simply must, for this year’s tour, acquire the rare yet adorable pseudocorn.

If the party agrees, Gavin and his homunculus business partner Squig explain how the party can locate a portal to the Brightlands and make their way to the court of Queen Amaryllis.

But what he doesn’t say is that it will take more than their arrival and search to uncover the pseudocorn—they’ll need to find gifts and attend the queen’s elaborate Hatching Day festival in order for her to bestow the creature upon them. But be cautious—the fae have rules, whims, and wiles of their own.

What's included with the adventure PDF:
This one-shot adventure includes four new creatures (plus variants!), one new magic item, and new fae plants, as well as a GM's and player's map of the Wandering Meadows in the Spring Fae Court.

There are two sets of fun randomizing tables to add variety and intrigue to your adventure, and you and your party will meet lots of interesting fae and friends along the way!

boardgame.name: So Many Problems: Your Mission
boardgame.description:
So Many Problems is a lightly competitive and deeply hilarious storytelling party game for 2 to 8 players. Your Mission (should you choose to accept it) is the first Deluxe Box, including four themes that won't self-destruct:
• Improvising Secret Agent is a master of physics and chemistry who can combine materials in unimaginable ways to escape from the most dangerous espionage assignments.
• You Meddlesome Youths bought a van, adopted a dog that sounds like he is trying to talk, and started a detective agency with some high school friends.
• Long Shot Astronaut and their crew face everything that can go terribly wrong in space, thinking on their feet while floating in zero-gravity.
• Not-So-Super Hero is fighting villains alongside heroes gifted with extreme strength or speed, even though they are basically just really good at a hobby like archery or martial arts.

Every round, each player gets three story elements to secretly distribute and a far-fetched problem to solve, all coming at random from the four themes. You'll try to give the other players elements that might help to solve their problems, but they don't actually want your help.

Before you look at the three elements you receive from others, shuffle in two random elements from the deck. Choose just three of those five possibly-helpful elements to use, trying to avoid those you suspect came from the other players, as you improvise and share a hilarious story that solves your problem.

You'll earn one point for each element you contributed to another player that was used in a solution. Each random element from the deck that you used in your own solution is worth one point, too. After three rounds of problems, the player with the most points wins! Optional advanced game modes add trophies to reward stories that are especially funny or creative, and actions like the challenge flag to throw down and crank up the competition.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Bricks & Brutes
boardgame.description:
Players race to complete their castle wall to their unique wall plan - the first one to complete their wall wins.

A players turn has three parts - first the player moves bricks from their unused brick pile up onto their castle wall. If the player has one Mason, they can move one brick. Two Masons - move two bricks.

The second part of a turn is when the player can use gold they have collected to buy more bricks for their unused pile, and hire more Masons (to help them build faster) and Brutes (to defend the unused brick pile and the player's Masons from the dragon).

The final part of the players turn is rolling a 1d10 - the DieOfFate. The die can get the player more gold and bricks, as well as three other possibilities: "Brute" - where (if you have Brutes) you can steal from another players unused brick pile, "Dragon" - where you send the dragon to eat another player's Brutes (or their Mason if they have no Brutes), and "Queen" - where everyone hands their unique castle wall plan to the player to their right - this means you could be one turn from winning with the final brick suddenly you need to reorganize the bricks on the top two levels of your wall.

The game goes fast and the twists and turns of the DieOfFate makes the game "self-leveling", everyone ends the game only a few turns from winning - nobody is completely and catastrophically behind when the game ends.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: BoardGains
boardgame.description:
Do you wish to bring your workouts to life? Working out on your own could get a little “boring” at times!

Imagine getting a chance to work on your fitness while having a fun time with your friends or likeminded people?

Sounds too good to be true? Well, it isn’t!

Because we bring you the BoardGains – Bodyweight Edition.

It is a fitness board game that lets you work on your fitness while having fun. This game engages you into a healthy competition all while allowing you to hit your fitness goals!

In this game, players or teams roll the dice, move their game piece, exercise, and collect gains. Win the game by collecting the set number of gains before anyone else or by collecting the most gains in a set amount of time.
Oh, and did we tell you that it comes with a twist? You betcha! BoardGains comes with “Lucky? Play Cards” that can either help you gain an advantage in the game or cause a disadvantage. It takes around 45 to 60 minutes to complete, and you can play anywhere.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Mexican Jack Squint Presents: The Lion Eats Tonight
boardgame.description:
The Lion Eats Tonight. This digest size title from the demented mind of Howard Whitehouse is all about the hunt for Big Game in the wilds of colonial Africa.

The game can be played with or without a gamemaster.

As players take turns trying to bag the best game, the other players will decide whether to award or subtract points depending on whether the hunter shot the charging rhino from the top of a tree or stood is ground as the beast charged directly toward him.

There are rules for tracking animals, stalking hunters, gun-bearers, and, of course, shooting with the best and worst guns of the time.
Realism is tossed out the window in place of a rip-roaring good time.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Shaman
boardgame.description:
12,000 years ago: the world is volatile, as are the prospects of survival for you and your tribe. A Shaman begins their duty as just a youth, but must be wise beyond his or her years in order to grow, expand and thrive as a tribe. As the spiritual leader you will decide when and where your tribe should hunt, gather, settle, build and more. The best Shamans commune freely with the spirits, animals and nature itself, but this path is not always peaceful, beasts will be slain and foes will be vanquished. Will your tribe grow and thrive or merely survive?

You are the Shaman leader of your specific tribe. Each Shaman has a collection of skulls in which they may commune with the spirit world. You must use these skulls to take actions, or harness a beast spirit, or even create and collect totems for bounties at your life's end. The actions you choose will tell your tribe to move, engage, grow, or worship, each having its own set of choices. In doing so, you will collect resources from the land to feed your tribe, to develop technologies, to build resources, make offerings to the great spirits, activate skulls and more. As the Shaman you must be wary of impending catastrophes known only to you and the other Shaman of the world. The Shaman whose tribe has the largest population is winner.

A tribe's total end game population consists of their total token dial amounts (rovers, warriors, villages), their totem bonus amounts, and any end game bonus population. The population represented by the dials underneath your tokens on the board will be the main portion of your score.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Checkermates
boardgame.description:
Checkers for 2 to 4 players. Each player sets up his/her checkers on the side of the board opposite to, and matching the named color, on the board perimeter. The board is big enough to accommodate all 4 players. Movement rules and capturing are identical with checkers and "kinging" is also a part of this game, occuring when a player's piece reaches the opposite side. The goal is to be last man standing. "Kingless" variants are given, with winning conditions depending on various goals for single pieces.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Dragonbrood
boardgame.description:
The dragons of Dracodale have long been banished to Eternal Slumber in the far corners of the Earth. But once a millennium, for just six years, the spirits of the Elder Dragons awaken to create new broods of Dragons to pillage the lands and collect immense hordes of treasure before being banished again to Eternal Slumber.

Each player is the spirit of an Elder Dragon: Black, Gray, Umber, Sienna, Tan, White, vying for the largest horde of treasure, including various coins, gems, jewels, trinkets, crystals, and gold. Players will begin with just a few young, freshly hatched dragons, but over the course of six years, each year consisting of four seasons, those few will grow in number and size, possibly even awaking your own slumbering Elder Dragon body. Players will ultimately, through clever choices of timing and possibly color abilities, be placing their Dragon meeples in various locations to gain, trade, steal, buy and spend various resources.

Each Elder Spirit’s horde of treasure is made up of their collection of the seven valuable items (gold, ducats (coin), gobloons (coin), dragon coin (coin), crystals, gems and jewels), as well as, trinkets obtained, bank vault value, magic track value and end game bonus amounts. The Elder Dragon Spirit (Player) with the most valuable horde of treasure at the end of the six years is the winner of Dragonbrood.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Conspiracy Theory Travel Edition
boardgame.description:
Conspiracy Theory tests your knowledge of the world of Internet conspiracies.

Answer questions to collect conspiracy cards to win, but be careful of Cover-Ups. A QR code is printed on every conspiracy card if you want more details (like when the ghost of JFK revealed that all dolphins are aliens).

The perfect party game for 2 to 6 players (or teams). This travel edition of our popular Conspiracy Theory Trivia Board Game, contains 200 all-new questions and a game die to easily play on the go (or use it as an expansion pack for the full board game).

-description from publisher's website
